title: Article 1
content: Sunday Morning Yes, there WAS good news coming out of 2020 sunday-morning By David Pogue December 27, 2020 / 9:33 AM EST / CBS News

title: Article 2
content: Correspondent David Pogue reminds us of some of the often-overshadowed bright spots of the past year. 2020 will not be remembered as a

title: Article 3
content: big year for good news. But science and technology actually scored a few triumphs – beginning with the piece of software that made it p

title: Article 4
content: ossible for meetings, classes, relationships, and performances to carry on. I'm referring, of course, to Zoom video calls, like the one

title: Article 5
content: I had with my 92-year-old dad, Cleveland lawyer Dick Pogue. "Hello, Dave!" "So, am I correct that you had never used Zoom until the loc

title: Article 6
content: kdown began?" "Absolutely not. I was amazed when I first saw it." "Apple, Google and Microsoft all had their own similar video programs

title: Article 7
content: . Why do you think Zoom became the winner of the pandemic?" David asked. "I think it's the simplicity of getting into the meeting."

title: Article 8
content: david-pogue-and-dick-pogue-via-zoom-620.jpg Despite a pandemic, Zoom has enabled Dick Pogue (right) to keep tabs on his son, David.

title: Article 9
content: CBS News All the Zoom meetings meant fewer people flying, and all the closed offices meant fewer people driving. It's not the kind of e

title: Article 10
content: conomy anybody wants, of course, but it did lead to some more good news: For the first time in a century, you could hear birdsong in th

title: Article 11
content: e cities; you could see fish in the canals of Venice; and you could see blue skies in L.A.! los-angeles-air-smog-and-smog-free-620.jpg

title: Article 12
content: Los Angeles air quality improved dramatically with the economic slowdown and stay-at-home orders resulting from the coronavirus pandemi

title: Article 13
content: c. CBS News At one point, global greenhouse gas emissions fell 17 percent, the biggest drop in human history. This was also the year th

title: Article 14
content: at the plastic pollution problem finally got the world's attention. We've dumping the equivalent of a truck-load's worth of plastic int

title: Article 15
content: o the ocean every minute of every day. China joined more than 125 other countries that have banned or taxed single-use plastic or plast

title: Article 16
content: ic bags. But you don't have to be a government to make a difference. Ordinary citizen Sheila Morovati was fed up with the more than 40

title: Article 17
content: billion plastic utensils that restaurants include with take-out orders every year that nobody uses. Pogue asked, "So, if I take it out

title: Article 18
content: of the takeout bag and throw it in the trash, that's not single-use plastic?" "That's zero-use plastic!" she replied. Moravati undertoo

content: k a one-woman campaign to persuade delivery services like Uber Eats and Postmates to make those utensils optional. "Uber Eats and Postm

content: ates now have a checkbox that says, 'If you would like plastic cutlery, click here.'" 2020 was also an astonishing year for space. NASA

title: Article 21
content: launched its most advanced rover yet to Mars; landed a spacecraft on an asteroid; and, for the first time since the Space Shuttle retir

content: ed in 2011, flew American astronauts to the International Space Station on an American spacecraft made by SpaceX - twice.

content: spacex-space-staiton-docking-111620.jpg The SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule, moments after docking at the International Space Station, Novem

content: ber 16, 2020. NASA Finally, 2020 ended with the best piece of news science could possibly have offered us: Vaccines for the disease tha

content: t ruined the year in the first place. Pogue asked, "Vaccines typically take years to develop – I mean, five, ten years. How was it poss

content: ible that this one was developed so fast?" "This was really born of a great deal of cooperation between academics, industry and governm

content: ent," said Pfizer's head of vaccine development Bill Gruber, "to essentially recognize this as the highest priority. One key element is

title: Article 28
content: that, as opposed to work typically being done in sequence, a great deal of work has been done in parallel." The vaccines hold the promi

content: se that this time next year, good news will be a lot easier to find.  At least that's what Pogue's dad thinks. David asked, "Do you hav

content: e any broader thoughts about the year 2020?" "I'll be glad when 2020's gone," Dick replied. "This was a bad year. But next year has got

title: Article 31
content: to be better, much better!" MoneyWatch Google's top trending search queries for 2020 highlight one of the strangest years of all time

title: Article 32
content: moneywatch By Dan Patterson Updated on: December 9, 2020 / 3:10 PM EST / MoneyWatch The COVID-19 pandemic, protests, wildfires and a hi

title: Article 33
content: gh-stakes presidential election: 2020 was one chaotic year, and a surge of people turned to Google for answers. Now the search giant ha

title: Article 34
content: s released the Year in Search, its annual snapshot of the year's most important search terms, news stories, entertainers and politician

title: Article 35
content: s. To create the annual list Google aggregates trillions — yes, trillions — of queries over the course of the year, filters out junk da

title: Article 36
content: ta like duplicate queries, then tabulates a list reflecting the events the company says most defined the year. To identify trends, Goog

title: Article 37
content: le's algorithm looks for the percentage increase in searches for a term over a period of time, relative to other searches.

title: Article 38
content: This year, searches for "election results" topped the list, and searches related to "coronavirus" were ubiquitous across categories. "K

title: Article 39
content: obe Bryant," "Joe Biden" and "stimulus checks" were also widely searched search terms. "One thing that has been incredible to see in th

title: Article 40
content: e data is the unprecedented shifts in people's information needs," said Google's data editor, Simon Rogers. For example, Google launche

title: Article 41
content: d a COVID-19 news page when its internal trend tracking tools flagged a spike in searches related to coronavirus. Instead of presenting

title: Article 42
content: a traditional page with search results, searches related to COVID-19 display timely and accurate information from vetted medical source

title: Article 43
content: s, like the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, World Health Organization and local news sources. "We worked with partners at t

title: Article 44
content: he international, national and even local levels to connect people with the critical info," Rogers explained. The page also used public

title: Article 45
content: data sources to display updated information like COVID-19 statistics in Google Maps. There were other atypical trends this year, Rogers

title: Article 46
content: said. The most interesting topics reflected how people adjusted to "a new normal. Queries about "Dalgona coffee," a popular comfort-foo

title: Article 47
content: d trend on social network TikTok, and "banana bread recipes" hit an all-time high, and questions about how to cut your own hair remaine

title: Article 48
content: d popular all year. "Fires near me" and "earthquake near me" were two of the top trending local queries this year. This year marks the

title: Article 49
content: 20th anniversary of Google's Year in Search. "Nostradamus," "osama bin laden" and "eminem" were the top queries when the list launched

title: Article 50
content: in 2001. At the time, the zeitgeist nature of the list was intended to demonstrate the scope of the fledgling startup's search technolo

title: Article 51
content: gy and user base and to differentiate Google in a once-crowded search-engine market, which included competitors like Yahoo!, AskJeeves

title: Article 52
content: and Inktomi. When the list launched it was just one simple webpage with a few subcategories. Today Google publishes hundreds of "trendi

title: Article 53
content: ng" categories in multiple languages. Here are some of Google's top trending search queries for 2020: Searches Election results

title: Article 54
content: Coronavirus Kobe Bryant Coronavirus update Coronavirus symptoms News Election results Coronavirus Stimulus checks Unemployment

title: Article 55
content: Iran People Joe Biden Kim Jong Un Kamala Harris Jacob Blake Ryan Newman, a NASCAR driver Politicians Joe Biden Kamala Harris

title: Article 57
content: December 30, 2020 / 11:18 AM EST / CBS News In cinema terms, 2020 is an asterisk year, at best. It was certainly not a great year for f

title: Article 58
content: ilm — choked in production, constrained and starved in exhibition, and forced to be viewed through the prism of a global crisis that co

title: Article 59
content: mpletely alters our reading of the movies and their messages. Most every film released this year was written, shot and edited before an

title: Article 60
content: yone had heard of the coronavirus, so their stories pretty much exist in a world that feels divorced from our current lives — escapism

title: Article 61
content: taken to the nth degree. Still, of those films whose releases weren't postponed to 2021 A.V. (After Vaccine), there was a choice select

title: Article 62
content: ion of movies worthy of a Ten Best Films list — and, thankfully, one great film that, pandemic or no, seems to exist outside of time.

title: Article 63
content: 1. "First Cow" Directed by Kelly Reichardt. Two enterprising young men in the Oregon Territory of 1820 conspire to steal milk from the

title: Article 64
content: first cow brought into the region, in order to sell their tasty biscuits at the muddy trading post that stands in for civilization. Mas

title: Article 65
content: terfully directed by Kelly Reichardt, "First Cow" is a primal drama of the American dream, and of people living on the periphery of wil

title: Article 66
content: derness, who would — in one fashion or another — help define a young nation's character. John Magaro's tender, inviting performance as

title: Article 67
content: Cookie, working his way west in hopes of finding his place in the world, pulls us into the character's conflict with his own sense of s

title: Article 68
content: hame. How far can he push himself beyond what would be considered the limits of acceptable behavior east of the Mississippi, when encou

title: Article 69
content: raged by Orion Lee's entrancing King-Lu, a personification of an American West opening its doors of opportunity to anyone with the braz

title: Article 70
content: enness and guts to enter? You feel Cookie's despoilment, and realize there can be no retreat, only a shared sense of commitment owing t

title: Article 71
content: o their friendship. And don't be fooled by the film's opening scene: The first several minutes are this gifted director's very effectiv

title: Article 72
content: e and haunting demonstration of the impermeable fabric of time, and how some of its mysteries can never, ever be resolved by us.

title: Article 147
content: This stunning recording of the Broadway stage sensation was slated to have a theatrical release in 2021. But when the pandemic shuttere

title: Article 148
content: d movie theaters — and postponed the summer release of the film version of Lin-Manuel Miranda's "In the Heights" — "Hamilton" was inste

title: Article 149
content: ad streamed on the Disney+ channel. Having the revolutionary musical on our home screens, while reductive, made the story of the foundi

title: Article 150
content: ng father more intimate, and the closeups of the actors capture their artistry in all its grandeur. At least, you didn't have to hope f

content: or a lottery win to score tickets to be in the room where it happens. Clip: "The Room Where It Happens" featuring Tony Award-winner Les

title: Article 153
content: But "Hamilton" also prompts a discussion of what exactly a movie is nowadays. With cinemas closed and many productions released straigh

title: Article 154
content: t to video-on-demand, what separates a "film" from the "content" that clogs our scrolling Netflix feed is becoming increasingly blurred

title: Article 155
content: . While the preferred method to watch a film will always be to gaze up at images projected on a giant blank wall, where you can give yo

title: Article 156
content: urself over to the story without distraction, a laptop will have to do if you don't want to chance spreading the infection to yourself

title: Article 157
content: or others. No movie (not even the Imax-sized "Tenet") is worth that risk. With regard to "Hamilton," there is little in the way of adap

title: Article 158
content: tation to a standard movie musical format, as Hollywood typically does; rather, it preserves the original Broadway cast, staging and co

title: Article 159
content: stumes, as contained on the stage of the Richard Rodgers Theatre, for which future generations can be grateful. But just as the show wa

title: Article 160
content: s a touchstone in musical theater, perhaps this recording of "Hamilton" will become a touchstone in a new kind of filmed performance, w

title: Article 161
content: ith no allegiance to realism or naturalism (as we have come to expect from movies, even fantastical ones). True, "First Cow" and "Nomad

title: Article 162
content: land" would be nowhere if they didn't travel where they did, but do we always need all the world as a stage, when you have ... a stage?

content: See also: RIP Ennio Morricone. Listen to 10 essential film scores by the Italian composer. Science The air got cleaner in 2020, thanks

title: Article 164
content: to the pandemic By Jeff Berardelli November 19, 2020 / 4:40 PM EST / CBS News The global pandemic has changed the way people live and w

title: Article 165
content: ork: fewer miles on the road commuting and in the air traveling, and a reduction in industry. The result? Cleaner air, with less haze a

title: Article 166
content: nd heat-trapping greenhouse gases, according to one report. The U.S. is on track to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from burning fossil

title: Article 167
content: fuels by more than 9% in 2020 compared with last year, according to research firm BloombergNEF. The last time yearly emissions were thi

title: Article 168
content: s low was 1983, nearly four decades ago. While the reductions were driven by a combination of decreases in various sectors, including p

title: Article 169
content: ower and industry, the largest drop was transportation, which declined 14% from 2019. Reductions like this — if sustained — help fight

title: Article 170
content: climate change by trapping less heat in the atmosphere. More heat trapped leads to higher global temperatures. But the report also cont

title: Article 171
content: ains bad news: Emissions from the historic wildfire season in the western U.S., which is partially driven by climate change, have been

title: Article 172
content: four times higher than the yearly average. acres-burned-new.png CBS News That jump in wildfire activity will offset the U.S. economy-wi

title: Article 173
content: de emissions drop by about 3%. But the U.S. should still post a 6.5% total decrease in emissions this year, according to the BloombergN

title: Article 174
content: EF report. That is almost the amount that experts say society needs to reduce emissions on a global scale for each of the next 10 years

title: Article 175
content: to keep the worldwide increase in temperature to less than 3 degrees Fahrenheit and avoid the worst impacts of climate change.

title: Article 176
content: Because the pandemic's effects will linger into 2021, the report predicts U.S. emissions will be down 5% next year compared with 2019 l

title: Article 177
content: evels. But a drop in emissions for a couple of years is merely a drop in the bucket. That's because greenhouse gases accumulate in the

title: Article 178
content: atmosphere and it is the cumulative emissions that determine how hot the planet gets and how bad the impacts of climate change become.

title: Article 179
content: Although China currently contributes the most emissions, according to the report, the U.S. is responsible for almost twice the cumulati

title: Article 180
content: ve emissions of any other nation since the start of the Industrial Revolution. The short term economic disruption caused by COVID-19 ha

title: Article 181
content: s inadvertently put the U.S. back on track to meet its commitments in the Paris Agreement, which President Donald Trump announced in 20

title: Article 182
content: 17 he would pull the country from. The U.S. is the only nation to drop out, but President-elect Joe Biden has said he will take action

title: Article 183
content: Day One to rejoin the pact. Once COVID-19 restrictions lift, the return of people to work and cars on the roads will make maintaining t

title: Article 184
content: he 2020 emissions reductions needed to keep global warming below international goals. If the nation does rejoin the Paris Agreement, th

title: Article 185
content: e BloombergNEF report says the U.S. will need stronger policy commitments outside of the power sector in order to hit its 2025 target.

title: Article 186
content: In other words, the U.S. will need to drastically reduce its dependence on fossil fuels to reach international goals. The international

title: Article 187
content: community is getting an assist from renewable energy because it is now the cheapest form of energy on the planet, according to the Inte

title: Article 188
content: rnational Energy Agency's 2020 Outlook, but experts say governments will need to implement robust policies to guide markets.

content: In: COVID-19 U.S. The record-shattering 2020 hurricane season, explained By Jeff Berardelli November 20, 2020 / 10:33 AM EST / CBS News

title: Article 193
content: Like so many other aspects of 2020, the Atlantic hurricane season hurled one shocking event after another, pushing the limits of what m

title: Article 194
content: eteorologists thought was possible. Even as longtime records were falling and meteorologists felt as though they'd seen it all, 2020 ha

title: Article 195
content: d more tricks up its sleeve. From the total number of storms to the rapid intensification and multiple landfalls, the records set in 20

title: Article 196
content: 20 will likely stand for quite some time. What follows is a recap of the season's most astonishing milestones with an explanation of th

title: Article 197
content: e factors that led to the events in this unprecedented season. Some of those factors are natural occurrences, while some are the result

title: Article 198
content: of human impact on the climate. Most storms in a season So far, the 2020 Atlantic hurricane season has spawned 30 tropical storms, forc

title: Article 199
content: ing forecasters to dig deep into the Greek alphabet for names, having run out of the assigned names in the middle of September. This br

title: Article 200
content: eaks the former record set in 2005 of 28 named storms. A typical season only produces 12 named storms, so 2020 has already seen two and

title: Article 201
content: a half times more than average. The 2020 Atlantic Hurricane Season to date: pic.twitter.com/kY7nb3A1ea — Tomer Burg (@burgwx) November

title: Article 202
content: 17, 2020 And there's still time for more storms. Hurricane season officially ends November 30, but  systems can and do form in December

title: Article 203
content: . So we're likely to add another couple of storms to the season total before the year is out. From the beginning there was unanimous ag

title: Article 204
content: reement among seasonal forecasters this past spring that 2020 would be an active season, with leading climate scientist Dr. Michael Man

title: Article 205
content: n of Penn State publishing the most aggressive forecast, predicting up to 24 storms. What seemed like a bold prediction at the time was

title: Article 206
content: not nearly bold enough. The unanimous expectations last spring illustrate that all of the variables that portend an active season appea

title: Article 207
content: red to be emerging months ahead of time. In fact, they not only emerged, but overlapped with one another. Everything just came together

title: Article 208
content: . North Atlantic sea surface temperatures were, and continue to be, far above normal in the entire basin, providing high-octane fuel to

title: Article 209
content: developing storms. Also, the West African monsoon, which ejects tropical disturbances into the far eastern Atlantic, some of which beco

title: Article 210
content: me hurricanes, was exceptionally active this summer. In the main development region of the Tropical Atlantic, surface pressures are amo

title: Article 211
content: ng the lowest in the historical record; low pressure equates to storminess. Lastly, there was an absence of El Niño in the Tropical Pac

title: Article 212
content: ific. It is a well established fact that El Niño events tend to kill Atlantic hurricanes because of the strong upper-level winds (wind

title: Article 213
content: shear) they produce. This year El Niño's opposite developed — La Niña — yielding a calm environment with less wind shear, which helped

title: Article 214
content: nurture developing storms. Then there's the elephant in the room: human-caused climate change. Since 1900, Tropical Atlantic ocean temp

title: Article 215
content: eratures have increased by 2 degrees Fahrenheit. While it's clear warmer ocean temperatures make storms stronger, there's still vigorou

title: Article 216
content: s debate among top climate scientists on the question of whether warmer waters lead to a greater number of tropical systems.

title: Article 217
content: "My colleagues and I feel that the jury is very much out on the topic of global tropical cyclone frequency," said Dr. Kerry Emanuel fro

title: Article 218
content: m MIT, a leading researcher on how climate change affects hurricanes. While this Atlantic season was extreme, he points out that what w

title: Article 219
content: e see in the Atlantic Basin is not representative of the rest of the globe. "Only about 12 percent of the world's tropical cyclones occ

title: Article 220
content: ur in the Atlantic, and globally it has not been a very exceptional year." Mann agrees, but leans towards what he feels is the more com

title: Article 221
content: pelling research he's seen, which points to more active seasons due to warming in the Atlantic. While some studies have found the oppos

title: Article 222
content: ite — suggesting a warming climate may lead to a decrease in storm numbers — Mann believes they used models that are insufficient to re

title: Article 223
content: solve the full spectrum of storms, which may have led to unrealistic results. Mann says because of the exponential relationship between

title: Article 224
content: warming and evaporation, the formation of tropical systems is not linear. Instead, he says, it is "threshold like," and his view is tha

title: Article 225
content: t "a warmer world is likely to see far greater tropical cyclogenesis," referring to the formation of tropical storms. For tropical stor

title: Article 226
content: ms to form, sea surface temperatures need to reach about 80 degrees Fahrenheit. It would stand to reason that since global warming has

title: Article 227
content: pushed sea surface temperatures up by 2 degrees in the Tropical Atlantic, then that threshold would be reached more often, in more geog

title: Article 228
content: raphical locations and at both earlier and later points in the season, breeding more spin-ups. Most storms to rapidly strengthen

title: Article 229
content: While the first half of the 2020 season included incessant storms, they were mainly weak. That changed during peak season, August throu

title: Article 230
content: gh October, and especially this autumn, no doubt owing partially to the development of the Pacific La Niña and the fact that the storms

title: Article 231
content: developed in the Caribbean — as they typically do during the fall — where some of the hottest waters in this hemisphere reside.

title: Article 232
content: Six of the last seven systems experienced rapid intensification — defined as an increase in winds of 35 mph in 24 hours. This would be

title: Article 233
content: unusual at any time of the year, but the fact that these were all Greek alphabet systems, having occurred so late in the season, makes

title: Article 234
content: it all the more remarkable. In total, 10 systems met the criteria for rapid intensification in 2020, tying a record established in the

title: Article 235
content: active 1995 season. Even more impressive is that a record four systems "rapidly deepened" in 2020, meaning the pressure dropped more th

title: Article 236
content: an 40 millibars in 24 hours. The two fastest pressure drops came at the tail-end of the season in November, when activity usually wanes

title: Article 237
content: — Hurricane Eta followed by Hurricane Iota. Simply put, this is unprecedented. But if you dig into the data the reason is clear. The we

title: Article 238
content: stern Caribbean is already the home to the highest ocean heat content in this part of the world. But climate change is quickly boosting

title: Article 239
content: that heat past thresholds which were rarely reached in the past. The warmer the water, the stronger a storm can get. The trend is clear

title: Article 240
content: in the red line below, showing the quick upward trend in the number of late-season days where sea surface temperatures exceed 83 degree

title: Article 241
content: s Fahrenheit. This is also supported by science. In Emanuel's 2017 paper, he finds that a storm intensifying 70 mph in the 24 hours bef

title: Article 242
content: ore landfall — a feat almost accomplished by Iota — used to occur only once per century as of the late 1900s, but by later this century

title: Article 243
content: it will happen once every 5 to 10 years. And this 2018 paper finds that rapid intensification has increased by 4.4 mph per decade since

title: Article 244
content: the 1980s, meaning if a hurricane increased its winds by 40 mph per day in 1980, then it would be likely to intensify by 60 mph per day

title: Article 245
content: now. Seven Category 5 storms in 5 years Until mid-November, one check-box left unchecked this season was a Category 5 hurricane. That c

title: Article 246
content: hanged when Hurricane Iota attained winds of 160 mph. It is the most intense storm on record that late in an Atlantic hurricane season.

title: Article 247
content: In each of the last five hurricane seasons we have seen at least one Category 5 hurricane — seven of them in total. This is a significa

title: Article 248
content: nt feat considering that in the last 170 years, the National Hurricane Center estimates there have only been 37 Category 5 storms. This

title: Article 249
content: means the chance of any given year yielding a Category 5, historically, is only about 20%. For the 1st time on record (since 1851), we

title: Article 250
content: have 5 straight years with a Category 5 #hurricane in the Atlantic. 2016: Matthew 2017: Irma/Maria 2018: Michael 2019: Dorian/Lorenzo

title: Article 251
content: Now in 2020, #Iota. The latest we've ever recorded a Cat. 5 in a year. Just the 2nd in November. pic.twitter.com/ejZiILvZm2

title: Article 252
content: — Jake Carstens (@JakeCarstens) November 16, 2020 It's not coincidence, it's climate change. In the past 120 years the Tropical Atlanti

title: Article 253
content: c has warmed 2 degrees Fahrenheit. Theoretically, for every 2-degree Fahrenheit increase in ocean warming, a storm can gain almost 20 m

title: Article 254
content: ph in peak wind speed. The latest research supports this trend in stronger storms. In a paper published earlier this year, NOAA's Dr. J

title: Article 255
content: ames Kossin found major hurricanes (Category 3, 4 and 5) are indeed increasing. Kossin told CBS News, "Globally, there's about a 25% gr

title: Article 256
content: eater chance now that a hurricane will be at major hurricane intensity than four decades ago. In the Atlantic there's about twice the c

title: Article 257
content: hance." This matters because the power and corresponding damage potential of a hurricane increases exponentially as the winds increase.

title: Article 258
content: In fact, 85% of the damage from all hurricanes is caused by the major hurricanes. So, if you have stronger hurricanes you are likely to

title: Article 259
content: have exponentially more damage. Record U.S. landfalls So far this season there have been 12 U.S. landfalls, shattering the old record o

title: Article 260
content: f nine set in 2016. In what was a relentless season for people living near the Gulf of Mexico, nine of this year's landfalls happened a

title: Article 261
content: long the U.S. Gulf Coast and five of them occurred in Louisiana. #Eta becomes the 12th named storm, and first in Florida, to make landf

title: Article 262
content: all on the U.S. mainland in 2020. This further creates separation from the previous record (9) set in 1916. pic.twitter.com/hEElsPOU1t

title: Article 263
content: — Steve Bowen (@SteveBowenWx) November 9, 2020 And in what may be the most freakish of occurrences, dual hurricane landfalls occurred j

title: Article 264
content: ust miles from each other on three occasions: Laura and Delta in Louisiana, Delta and Zeta in Mexico's Yucatan, and Eta and Iota in Nic

title: Article 265
content: aragua. Where 2020 fell short While 2020 overperformed in nearly every category, there is one surprising statistic which was not all th

title: Article 266
content: at impressive: Accumulated Cyclone Energy (ACE). This is a widely used metric for meteorologists to estimate the intensity of a hurrica

title: Article 267
content: ne season because it is an aggregation of the strength and longevity of all storms. To be sure, ACE was far above the normal season, bu

title: Article 268
content: t it fell far short of what would be expected for 30 storms. To date, the total ACE for the 2020 hurricane season is 178, nowhere near

title: Article 269
content: the record of 245 set in 2005. That's because 2005 also had four Category 5 hurricanes, compared to only one this year; more hurricanes

title: Article 270
content: overall than 2020; and longer lasting storms, too. The 2004 season, featuring hurricanes Charley and Ivan, had only half the number of

title: Article 271
content: storms of 2020 yet produced more ACE. So why did 2020 underperform in the ACE department? One reason is that the first half of the seas

title: Article 272
content: on produced mostly weak systems. And unlike 2005, when many of the hurricanes were long-track storms, most of the strongest storms in 2

title: Article 273
content: 020 formed closer to land so they did not last as long. This was especially true for the end-of-season Greek alphabet named storms, man

title: Article 274
content: y of which formed in the Caribbean and made landfall shortly thereafter. They just did not have the time to accumulate as much ACE.

title: Article 275
content: While many of the records set in 2020 will likely stay in the record books for years to come, one thing is certain: As long as society

title: Article 276
content: continues to release heat-trapping greenhouse pollution, climate change will continue to power hurricane seasons that defy the odds.

title: Article 472
content: U.S. Thousands gather for 2020 March on Washington By Audrey McNamara Updated on: August 28, 2020 / 5:08 PM EDT / CBS News

title: Article 473
content: Fifty-seven years after Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech at the March on Washington, the families of Black Americans sh

title: Article 474
content: ot or killed by police officers spoke at the same site Friday, the Lincoln Memorial in Washington D.C. The families of George Floyd, Br

title: Article 475
content: eonna Taylor, Eric Garner and Jacob Blake joined Reverend Al Sharpton and Martin Luther King III at the Commitment March: Get Your Knee

title: Article 476
content: off Our Necks, which drew an estimated thousands. The march, organized by the National Action Network, was calling for racial justice a

title: Article 477
content: nd police reform. Sharpton first announced plans for the march during a memorial service for George Floyd, the 46-year-old father who d

title: Article 478
content: ied at the hands of police in Minneapolis in May. "George Floyd's story has been the story of Black folks because ever since 401 years

title: Article 479
content: ago, the reason we could never be who we wanted and dreamed to be is you kept your knee on our neck," Sharpton said at the service in J

title: Article 480
content: une. "It's time for us to stand up in George's name and say, 'Get your knee off our necks!'" George Floyd's brother, Philonise Floyd, t

title: Article 481
content: old the crowd Friday he was overwhelmed by the support, and said he wished "George were here to see this right now." His sister, Bridge

title: Article 482
content: tt Floyd, said, "we have to be the change." The mothers of Dontre Hamilton, Trayvon Martin and Ahmaud Arbery also spoke.

title: Article 483
content: "Even though we're going through a crisis, even though it looks dark, I want to tell you to be encouraged," said Martin's mother Sybrin

title: Article 484
content: a Fulton. "Don't stop saying Black lives matter, don't stop protesting," she said. In the months since Floyd's death, Black Lives Matte

title: Article 485
content: r marches have proliferated across the country. Protesters continue to call for justice for the officers charged in Floyd's death, and

title: Article 486
content: those involved in other controversial cases including the death of Breonna Taylor, who was shot and killed by officers in her own home

title: Article 487
content: in Louisville, and Elijah McClain, who died after a police chokehold in Aurora, Colorado, last summer. Protests erupted again this week

title: Article 488
content: following the shooting of Jacob Blake in Kenosha, Wisconsin. Blake, a 29-year-old Black man, was hospitalized after police shot him sev

title: Article 489
content: eral times in the back as he opened the door of his parked car. Attorneys for his family say he is now paralyzed. Blake's father spoke

title: Article 490
content: at the march on Friday, and used it as an opportunity to "hold court" against systematic racism in America. "We're going to have court

title: Article 491
content: right now. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Racism against all of us. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty," he said. "… And we're not taking it anymore."

title: Article 492
content: "We're going to stand up, every Black person in the United States is going to stand up," he said. "We're tired. I'm tired of looking at

title: Article 493
content: cameras and seeing these young Black and Brown people suffer." His words, spoken on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial, come 57 years af

title: Article 494
content: ter his own father attended the original March on Washington, according to Blake. "I have a duty," he said. "I have a duty to support a

title: Article 495
content: nd understand each one — I love everybody in this crowd, I love you." Democratic vice presidential nominee Kamala Harris recorded brief

title: Article 496
content: remarks for the march that played during the event on Friday. Harris, who tweeted her address Thursday night, said that if civil rights

title: Article 497
content: activists from the 1960s were here today, they "would share in our anger and frustration as we continue to see Black men and women slai

title: Article 498
content: n in our streets and left behind by an economy and justice system that have too often denied Black folks our dignity and rights."

title: Article 499
content: "They would share our anger and pain, but no doubt they would turn it into fuel," Harris continued. "They would be lacing up their shoe

title: Article 500
content: s, locking arms and continuing right alongside us to continue in this ongoing fight for justice." Harris said Americans are once again

title: Article 501
content: in a position to make history. "The road ahead is not going to be easy," she said, adding, "we have an opportunity to make history, rig

title: Article 502
content: ht here and right now." Other lawmakers spoke about the need to pass legislation crafted to confront racial injustice. Texas Congressma

title: Article 503
content: n Sheila Jackson Lee asked the crowd, "how did this happen?" answering, "because of institutional racism." Lee urged for the passage of

title: Article 504
content: her bill H.R. 40, which would establish a commission to "study and develop reparation proposals for African-Americans." Congresswoman J

title: Article 505
content: oyce Beatty, a member of the Congressional Black Caucus, demanded that the Voting Rights Act of 1965 be fully restored. The act establi

title: Article 506
content: shed federal oversight of election laws in states with a history of racial discrimination, but key sections of the legislation were str

title: Article 507
content: uck down by the Supreme Court in 2013. The late Congressman John Lewis spent much of his life fighting for voting rights and was a cham

title: Article 508
content: pion of the act, which passed in part because of his march in Selma, Alabama. Lewis continued to fight for its restoration until his de

title: Article 509
content: ath in July. "We are here today because people died, and were denied basic civil rights," Beatty said. "... John Lewis left us with mar

title: Article 510
content: ching orders." Reverend Al Sharpton also invoked Lewis in his speech. With a nod to his advocacy of getting into "good trouble," Sharpt

title: Article 511
content: on said, "we didn't come to start trouble, we came to stop trouble." "Black lives matter," Sharpton said. "And we won't stop until it m

title: Article 512
content: atters to everybody." Tim Perry contributed to this report. Face The Nation Full transcript of "Face the Nation" on August 23, 2020

content: 020: "A staggering loss of human life" Updated on: July 14, 2021 / 7:01 PM EDT / AP Overdose deaths soared to a record 93,000 last year

title: Article 1889
content: in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, the U.S. government reported Wednesday. That provisional estimate by the Centers for Disease Con

title: Article 1890
content: trol and Prevention far eclipses the high of about 72,000 drug overdose deaths reached the previous year and amounts to a 29% increase.

title: Article 1891
content: "This is a staggering loss of human life," said Brandon Marshall, a Brown University public health researcher who tracks overdose trend

title: Article 1892
content: s. The nation was already struggling with its worst overdose epidemic but clearly "COVID has greatly exacerbated the crisis," he added.

title: Article 1893
content: Lockdowns and other pandemic restrictions isolated those with drug addictions and made treatment harder to get, experts said.

title: Article 1894
content: Jordan McGlashen died of a drug overdose in his Ypsilanti, Michigan, apartment last year. He was pronounced dead on May 6, the day befo

title: Article 1895
content: re his 39th birthday. Drug Overdoses Record This August 2017 provided by the family shows Jordan McGlashen, left, and his brother, Coll

title: Article 1896
content: in. Jordan died of a drug overdose in his Ypsilanti, Mich, apartment in 2020. / AP "It was really difficult for me to think about the w

title: Article 1897
content: ay in which Jordan died. He was alone, and suffering emotionally and felt like he had to use again," said his younger brother, Collin M

title: Article 1898
content: cGlashen, who wrote openly about his brother's addiction in an obituary. Jordan McGlashen's death was attributed to heroin and fentanyl

title: Article 1899
content: . While prescription painkillers once drove the nation's overdose epidemic, they were supplanted first by heroin and then by fentanyl,

title: Article 1900
content: a dangerously powerful opioid, in recent years. Fentanyl was developed to treat intense pain from ailments like cancer but has increasi

title: Article 1901
content: ng been sold illicitly and mixed with other drugs. "What's really driving the surge in overdoses is this increasingly poisoned drug sup

title: Article 1902
content: ply," said Shannon Monnat, an associate professor of sociology at Syracuse University who researches geographic patterns in overdoses.

title: Article 1903
content: "Nearly all of this increase is fentanyl contamination in some way. Heroin is contaminated. Cocaine is contaminated. Methamphetamine is

title: Article 1904
content: contaminated." There's no current evidence that more Americans started using drugs last year, Monnat said. Rather, the increased deaths

title: Article 1905
content: most likely were people who had already been struggling with addiction. Some have told her research team that suspensions of evictions

title: Article 1906
content: and extended unemployment benefits left them with more money than usual. And they said "when I have money, I stock up on my (drug) supp

title: Article 1907
content: ly," she said. Overdose deaths are just one facet of what was overall the deadliest year in U.S. history. With about 378,000 deaths att

title: Article 1908
content: ributed to COVID-19, the nation saw more than 3.3 million deaths. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reviewed death certifi

title: Article 1909
content: cates to come up with the estimate for 2020 drug overdose deaths. The estimate of over 93,000 overdose deaths translates to an average

title: Article 1910
content: of more than 250 deaths each day, or roughly 11 every hour. The 21,000 increase is the biggest year-to-year jump since the count rose b

title: Article 1911
content: y 11,000 in 2016. More historical context: According to the CDC, there were fewer than 7,200 total U.S. overdose deaths reported in 197

title: Article 1912
content: 0, when a heroin epidemic was raging in U.S. cities. There were about 9,000 in 1988, around the height of the crack epidemic.

title: Article 1913
content: The CDC reported that in 2020 drug overdoses increased in all but two states: New Hampshire and South Dakota. Kentucky's overdose count

title: Article 1914

title: Article 1915
content: t Virginia and California. Vermont had the largest jump, of about 58%, but smaller numbers — 118 to 186. The proliferation of fentanyl

title: Article 1916
content: is one reason some experts do not expect any substantial decline in drug overdose deaths this year. Though national figures are not yet

title: Article 1917
content: available, there is data emerging from some states that seems to support their pessimism. Rhode Island, for example, reported 34 overdo

title: Article 1918
